seed_text: As a child, my parents injured my brother, so they went to prison. I was there when he had gotten hurt, but I can't seem to remember. I also can't remember being with them quite well. It's a blur.

transcript.content: Hello, and welcome. I'm glad you're here. Before we get started, I want to make sure our conversations are comfortable and helpful for you. Some people prefer a more direct style where we focus on clear feedback and solutions, while others prefer a reflective style, focusing on exploring feelings and thoughts together. Which communication style do you think would work best for you?
I think I’d prefer a more reflective style. I want to understand what’s going on in my mind, since so much of my childhood feels like a blur.

Thank you for sharing that. I understand you want to take a reflective approach to exploring your memories and feelings. From what you described, it sounds like your childhood was impacted by a serious event involving your brother and your parents, and you have difficulty remembering the details. Could you tell me a little more about what brings you here today and what you hope to gain from our sessions?
I want to figure out why I can’t remember what happened or what my parents were like. I feel disconnected from that whole part of my life, and I want to understand myself better.

That makes sense, and it’s understandable to want to make sense of those blank spots. It sounds like understanding your past, reconnecting with your memories, and gaining insight into yourself are important to you. As we continue, please let me know if there’s anything specific you’d like to focus on, or if our approach needs to shift to make you feel more comfortable.

Thank you for being open about what you’re experiencing. You mentioned that your childhood memories, especially of your parents and your brother’s injury, feel blurry and disconnected. That sounds both confusing and painful. Could you tell me what feelings come up for you when you try to think back to that time?

It’s strange, because sometimes I feel nothing at all. Other times, I get this mix of anxiety and guilt, like there’s something I should remember, or maybe something I did wrong. But I don’t actually know what happened, or what I was feeling back then.

It sounds like there’s a lot of uncertainty, and that not knowing makes space for difficult feelings like guilt and anxiety. Not remembering is actually a common response to overwhelming or traumatic events—it can be a way your mind protects you. When you think about your parents or your brother, are there any images, sensations, or bits of memory that come up at all, or is it mostly blank?

Mostly blank, honestly. Sometimes I get these flashes—like a hospital room, or voices arguing, but it’s like watching a TV on mute from another room. I don’t know if those are real memories or something I imagined after hearing stories later.

That image of watching a TV on mute from another room is a powerful way to describe it. It can be hard to trust what’s real in those fragments, especially if you’ve also heard other people’s versions of the story. When you do get those flashes, do you notice any physical sensations in your body, or changes in how you feel emotionally?
Sometimes my chest feels tight, or my stomach drops. I think I get tense, but it’s not always clear why. There’s a sense of dread sometimes, or like I want to just look away.

That’s very understandable. Our bodies can hold onto feelings even when our minds can’t recall the details. The tension, the urge to look away, and that physical heaviness can all be signs that something was very difficult or frightening, even if the memories themselves aren’t clear. If it’s okay with you, we can take this process slowly, checking in with how you’re feeling as we explore together. Is there a time or place from your childhood—not necessarily related to the injury or your parents—where you do have clear memories? Or does most of your early life feel distant?

Most of my early life just feels far away, like it happened to someone else. If I try really hard, I can remember some things—like my brother and I playing with blocks when we were little, or us sitting on the floor watching cartoons. But even those memories are fuzzy around the edges. Nothing about my parents stands out, except maybe a feeling of being careful, like I was watching them more than being with them.

Thank you for sharing that. The sense of distance, like your early life happened to someone else, can be unsettling. It's interesting that you have a few memories with your brother, even if they're a bit fuzzy. That feeling of being careful, of watching your parents instead of being fully present with them, stands out to me. Sometimes, growing up in an unpredictable or unsafe environment can make children become very alert to others' moods or actions. Does that idea resonate with you at all?

I think so. I remember always feeling like I had to be quiet or not make trouble, though I don't know why exactly. There’s a sense of walking on eggshells, maybe, but I just assumed that was normal. It’s strange that I can remember these feelings more than anything they actually said or did.

That makes a lot of sense. Sometimes our minds remember emotions and sensations more clearly than specific events, especially if those feelings were strong or lasted a long time. The fact that you recall needing to be quiet or not make trouble could be an important clue about your environment growing up. It sounds like you were carrying a lot, even as a child. As we continue, we can explore these feelings further, and see if any other memories or insights begin to surface for you. How do you feel now, having talked about these early impressions?

A little sad, I guess, but also relieved that I can at least put some words to it. I always thought I just didn’t remember because there was nothing important, but maybe it’s more about how things felt than what actually happened.

That’s a really insightful observation. Sometimes, the absence of clear memories is itself a kind of message about what it was like for you as a child. The feelings you do recall—sadness, caution, relief now—can be valuable guides as we keep piecing things together. We can take this at your pace, focusing on understanding and compassion for what your younger self experienced. If anything comes up between sessions, or if you feel overwhelmed, please know we can pause and return to steadier ground whenever you need.

Thank you for coming back and being willing to keep exploring this, even if it feels hard right now. It sounds like you’ve been feeling a sense of setback or frustration about not being able to remember what happened when your brother was hurt, or what your parents were like. I want to acknowledge that this is an incredibly tough situation, and that not remembering doesn’t mean you’re doing anything wrong. Can you tell me a bit more about what’s felt especially difficult for you lately?

I just feel stuck again. I know my parents hurt my brother and that’s why they went to prison, but I can’t remember any of it or even what it was like being around them. I was there when it happened, but it’s like my brain just erased everything. I keep thinking maybe if I try harder, something will come back, but it always feels blank or jumbled. It’s overwhelming to think about, and then I feel guilty for not remembering or for not stopping it—except I don’t even know what actually happened.

That sounds incredibly overwhelming and painful—a mix of feeling stuck, guilty, and frustrated by the blankness. It’s very common for our minds to protect us from memories that are too painful or frightening to process when we’re young. The fact that these memories are blurred or missing isn’t a failure on your part; it’s a sign of just how difficult that environment was for you. When the guilt or frustration comes up, do you notice any changes in your body, or thoughts that get louder?

I get tense, like my shoulders and jaw clench up, and I feel this sinking feeling in my stomach. Sometimes I just want to hide or distract myself. My thoughts go in circles—like maybe I should just remember, or maybe I’m making it up, or maybe I could have done something if I hadn’t been so quiet all the time.

It sounds exhausting to be caught in that loop—blaming yourself, doubting your own mind, feeling tense and wanting to disappear. I want to gently remind you that as a child, you did what you needed to do to survive a very frightening situation. The urge to be quiet or careful wasn’t a choice you made lightly; it was likely the safest thing you could do at the time. The fact that you can recognize these feelings now is a sign of your strength and resilience, even if it doesn’t feel that way. Would it feel okay to talk about some ways you might offer compassion to your younger self, or is there something else coming up for you that you’d like to focus on right now?

Thank you for being here and for sharing so openly about how challenging and stuck things have felt. I want to acknowledge again that feeling blank, frustrated, or guilty is a very human response to the kind of overwhelming experiences you went through. Sometimes, even just naming these feelings and noticing how they show up in your body is an important part of the healing process. As you think about this setback and what we’ve explored so far, what stands out to you the most about how you’ve been handling all of this?

I guess what stands out is how much I keep blaming myself, even when I know, logically, that I was just a kid. It’s like part of me can see that I was just trying to stay safe, but another part still feels like it was my fault for not doing more or remembering more. It’s weird, but just saying that makes me realize how hard I’ve been on myself.

That’s a really powerful realization. It sounds like there’s a part of you that’s been holding onto responsibility or blame, even though you can also see, as an adult, that you did what you needed to survive. This kind of self-blame is so common for people who have lived through trauma—especially when memories are missing or unclear. Sometimes, offering compassion to those younger parts of ourselves can be a way to start shifting those old beliefs. As you notice the urge to blame yourself, does anything shift for you when you try to imagine responding with understanding or kindness instead?

It’s hard, honestly. When I try to be kind to myself, it feels uncomfortable, like I don’t deserve it. But I also feel a little relief, like maybe it’s possible that it wasn’t all my fault. I just wish I could believe it more.

That makes a lot of sense. Self-compassion can feel unfamiliar or even unsafe at first, especially after years of carrying guilt or self-criticism. Even noticing a small sense of relief is important—it means there’s a part of you that wants to heal. We don’t have to force anything; just being gentle with yourself in these moments, like you’re practicing now, is a meaningful step. As we wrap up today, would you be open to noticing when these self-blaming thoughts come up this week, and gently seeing if you can offer even a small amount of understanding to yourself in those moments? Next time, we could talk together about what you notice.
I can try. I’m not sure how good I’ll be at it, but I’ll notice when I’m being hard on myself and see if I can be a little more understanding, even if it’s just for a second.

That’s all I could ask for. Even just noticing is a powerful first step. We’ll go at your pace. So, for next session, let’s agree that your task is to pay attention to those moments of self-blame and experiment—very gently—with offering yourself understanding instead of criticism, even briefly. We’ll explore together what comes up for you. How does that sound?
That sounds okay. I’ll do my best and let you know what happens.

Welcome back. I want to start by checking in on how things have been for you since our last session. You agreed to notice moments when you felt self-blame and to gently try offering yourself a bit of understanding or compassion instead, even if just for a moment. What was that experience like for you this past week?

I've tried to notice when I'm being hard on myself, like we talked about. Sometimes I catch it and can pause, but other times it just gets really overwhelming. This week, there were a couple of days when it felt pointless to even try—like no matter what, I just end up back in that same place of feeling like nothing will get better. I started thinking maybe it would be easier if I could just disappear for a while. I don’t know, I feel kind of stuck and exhausted, and part of me wonders if I’ll ever stop feeling this way.

seed_text: At a friend's house, we had some drinks and watched some television. He got up and went to bed. I felt sick. He came out to see if I was okay, and I said no. I said I wanted to go home, and he told me to come lay down. As I laid down on the bed, he started touching me. A friend called me, then I able to leave.

transcript.content: Thank you for sharing what happened at your friend's house. That sounds like it was a very difficult and confusing experience. Before we begin working together, I want to make sure that our sessions are as helpful and comfortable as possible for you. Some people prefer a direct communication style—clear, solution-focused feedback and guidance. Others prefer a more reflective style—where I help you process your feelings by listening and asking questions, letting you lead the pace. Do you have a preference for how we communicate in our sessions?
I think I would prefer a reflective style. I need space to talk things out and make sense of what happened, rather than jumping straight into solutions.

Thank you for letting me know. We'll focus on creating space for you to process your thoughts and feelings at your own pace. You mentioned feeling sick and wanting to leave, and that your friend touched you after you said you weren't okay. That sounds like a violation of your boundaries. As we start our work together, could you share what’s most important to you right now, or any values that are guiding you as you process this experience? Are there any specific goals you have for these sessions?

Right now, I just want to understand what happened and why I feel the way I do. I value honesty and respect, and I want to feel safe and trust myself again. My goal is to stop blaming myself and to figure out how to deal with the feelings that keep coming up.

Thank you for sharing your values and your goals. Honesty, respect, safety, and self-trust are all important, and it's understandable that you want to understand your feelings and stop blaming yourself. We will take things at your pace and focus on helping you process your experience in a way that feels right to you.

Thank you for coming back and for your openness so far. Last time, you shared some of what happened at your friend's house, and I hear that this experience has left you with a lot of confusing feelings. If it feels okay, can you tell me more about what comes up for you when you think about that night? Are there certain moments that stand out, or feelings that keep returning?

It's hard to talk about. I keep thinking about when I said I wasn't okay and wanted to go home. I remember feeling sick and kind of out of it. When he told me to lay down, I just wanted to get away from feeling so bad, and I didn't really know what else to do. But then when he touched me, I felt frozen. I couldn't say anything. Afterward, I keep replaying that moment and wondering why I didn't do more to stop it.

It sounds like that moment left you feeling powerless and maybe even confused about your response. It's very common to freeze in situations like this—it's a natural reaction when we feel threatened or overwhelmed. When you find yourself replaying that moment, what kinds of emotions or thoughts tend to come up?

I feel a mix of shame and anger—mostly at myself, but sometimes at him. I keep thinking maybe I gave the wrong signals or maybe I should have left earlier. I also feel sad, like I lost some trust in myself.

Thank you for being so honest about these feelings. It's understandable to feel a mix of shame, anger, and sadness after what happened. Many people blame themselves in these situations, even though it's not their fault. When you say you've lost some trust in yourself, can you tell me a bit more about what that means to you?
I keep questioning my judgment, like, why did I stay? Why didn't I do something different? I worry that I won't know how to protect myself if something like this happens again.

It makes a lot of sense that you'd be questioning yourself after such a confusing and hurtful experience. Loss of trust in yourself can feel really destabilizing. As we talk about this, are there particular memories—either from this night or from earlier in your life—that feel connected to these feelings or doubts about your ability to protect yourself?

I think I've always had trouble saying no or standing up for myself, even as a kid. I remember times when I didn't feel listened to, so I guess I've gotten used to just going along with things, even when I don't want to.

Thank you for sharing that. It sounds like this experience might be tapping into some older patterns of not feeling heard or able to assert your needs. That can make these kinds of moments especially hard. How does it feel to talk about these connections between the past and what happened with your friend?

Thank you for your openness last time and for exploring some of those connections between the past and what happened at your friend's house. As we continue, I want to make sure we’re going at a pace that feels manageable for you. Looking back on what we’ve talked about, are there any new thoughts or feelings that have come up for you since our last session?

A little bit, yeah. I’ve been thinking about how I’ve always just kind of gone along with things when I’m uncomfortable, and that maybe it’s not just about this one night. I still feel a lot of guilt and wish I had done something different, but I’m starting to see that my response wasn’t really a choice in the moment. I was just… overwhelmed.

That’s a really important realization. It sounds like you’re beginning to understand that your reaction—freezing or going along with things—wasn’t a failure on your part, but more of an automatic response, especially when you felt overwhelmed or powerless. How does it feel to think about it in that way?

It’s kind of a relief, actually. I don’t know if I believe it all the way yet, but it helps a little to consider that I wasn’t just making bad choices. It’s hard to let go of the guilt, but maybe I can be a little less harsh with myself.

That makes a lot of sense. Letting go of guilt is a process, and it’s okay if you’re not there yet. Being less harsh with yourself, even just a little, can be a meaningful step. As you notice these feelings and thoughts shifting, is there anything you find yourself wanting or needing from yourself right now? Or from others?
I think I just want some understanding and patience—from myself, mostly. I wish I could talk to someone about it without worrying they’ll judge me. I know I need time to process all of this.

That’s very understandable. Giving yourself patience and understanding is really important, especially as you work through something so difficult. You deserve support and kindness, both from yourself and from others. As we continue, we can keep focusing on creating that non-judgmental space, and go at whatever pace feels right for you. Is there anything, in particular, you’d like to talk more about today or any questions you have for me?

Thank you for coming back and for your honesty so far. Before we check in, I want to remind you that it's normal for healing to have ups and downs—sometimes things can feel like they're getting better, and then a wave of difficult feelings comes up again. Has anything happened recently that's brought some of those feelings back, or made things feel harder?

Yeah, actually, I had a rough week. I thought I was starting to feel a little better, but then I saw a post online about someone else's experience and it kind of set me off. I started replaying everything again—thinking about that night, and just feeling stuck. It all came back: the guilt, the anger at myself, and even the feeling of being frozen. I felt like I was back at square one.

I'm really sorry you're going through that. It sounds like seeing that post was really triggering and brought back a lot of the feelings and memories you've been working to process. It's understandable that those emotions would come up again—especially when you're reminded so vividly of what happened. When you say it felt like you were back at square one, what was that experience like for you, emotionally or physically?

It was overwhelming. My heart was racing, and I felt kind of numb but also panicky at the same time. I just kept thinking, "Why am I still stuck? Why can’t I move past this?" I felt like I was blaming myself again, even though I know, logically, it wasn't my fault.

That sounds incredibly difficult. It's so common for old feelings of blame or shame to resurface, especially when you're reminded of what happened. Even as you start to understand, logically, that it wasn't your fault, the emotional part of you might still struggle. When those feelings come up—like the racing heart, numbness, or panic—how do you usually respond to yourself in those moments?
Honestly, I just try to distract myself or shut it down. I don't really know how to comfort myself. Sometimes I tell myself to get over it, but that mostly just makes me feel worse.

It makes sense that you'd want to push those feelings away—they're painful, and it's natural to want to avoid them. Sometimes, though, that can make the feelings even more intense. Would it feel okay to talk together about what it might be like to respond to yourself with a little more understanding or gentleness in those moments? Or is there something else you feel you need right now as we talk about this setback?
I think talking about responding to myself with more understanding might help. I don’t really know how to do that, but I’m willing to try.

Thank you for your openness and willingness to explore this. It’s not easy to shift from shutting things down to offering yourself understanding, especially after what you’ve been through. If it feels okay, can we start by imagining how you might respond to a friend who was feeling overwhelmed and blaming themselves the way you have been? What kinds of things might you say to them?
I’d probably tell them it wasn’t their fault, that they did the best they could. I’d want them to know it’s normal to feel this way and that it doesn’t mean they’re weak or broken.

That’s really compassionate. Sometimes, it can be helpful to turn that same kindness toward yourself—even if it feels strange at first. When those intense feelings come up, you might try reminding yourself: 'I did the best I could in a really hard situation,' or, 'It’s okay to feel this way.' How does it feel to consider talking to yourself in this way?
It feels kind of awkward and maybe even a little fake, but I think I’d like to try. I’m tired of feeling like I have to just push everything down.

That makes sense. These kinds of changes can feel awkward at first, but over time, practicing gentle self-talk can help shift the way you relate to these difficult feelings. Even just being willing to try is a really important step. Looking back at everything we’ve talked about—from understanding your reactions, to the waves of blame and shame, and now considering self-compassion—what stands out to you as something meaningful you’re taking from our work so far?

I think the biggest thing is realizing that my reactions make sense—they weren’t something I chose, and I can learn to be less harsh with myself. I’m starting to see that healing takes time, and that it’s okay if I have setbacks.

That’s a powerful realization. Recognizing that your reactions were automatic—not your fault—and that setbacks are a normal part of healing, can help you approach yourself with more patience and care. For our next session, would you be open to trying a small practice of gentle self-talk when difficult feelings come up, and then reflecting together on what that experience was like for you?
Yeah, I can try that. I’m not sure how it’ll go, but I’ll pay attention to what happens and we can talk about it next time.

Thank you for your willingness. For next time, just notice any moments when tough feelings arise, and gently try responding to yourself the way you might comfort a friend. There’s no right or wrong way—whatever you notice will be helpful for us to explore. We’ll talk about what that was like for you when we meet again.

Welcome back. Last time, we talked about practicing gentle self-talk or self-compassion when difficult feelings come up, and you agreed to notice what that experience was like for you. Before we get started, I just want to check in—how did it go for you this past week? Were there any moments where you were able to try responding to yourself with kindness, or anything you noticed about how that felt?

I tried, but it was harder than I expected. There was a situation at work where someone made an offhand comment that made me feel kind of stupid. My first reaction was the usual—just beating myself up for not saying or doing the right thing. I remembered what we talked about, and I tried telling myself it was okay to feel upset, and that I wasn’t a failure just because of one awkward moment. But part of me kept arguing back, like, 'You’re just making excuses.' I ended up feeling confused about which voice to listen to. Is that normal?

seed_text: At school, it feels like I've lost all my friends, and I've been really weird with my sleeping patterns. I used to cut myself, and I really want to again, but I change in the locker rooms because I don’t want anybody to see. I get ticked off easy and overreact. At night, I’m very depressed and listen to sad music and all that sort of stuff. Please help me. I just want to be happy again, and I feel like I’m starting to fake a smile at school.

transcript.content: Hi, welcome. I'm really glad you reached out today—sharing what you're going through takes a lot of courage. Before we get started, can I ask about your preferred communication style? Some people like direct, straightforward advice, while others prefer a more reflective approach, where we talk things through and explore feelings together. Which would you feel most comfortable with?
I think I would prefer if you were pretty direct with me. I get frustrated when people are too vague or just repeat what I say. I want to know what to do to feel better.

Thank you for letting me know. I'll be as clear and direct as possible. From what you described, it sounds like you’re feeling really isolated at school, your sleep is all over the place, and you’re struggling with urges to self-harm again. You mentioned feeling angry and overwhelmed, and that you want to be happy again instead of faking a smile. To help me support you better, can you share a little about what’s most important to you right now—what you value, or what you’d like to work toward?

I just want to be able to feel like myself again. I want real friends and not to feel like I’m pretending all the time. I also want to stop thinking about hurting myself, because I don’t want to get stuck in that again. I guess I want to actually feel happy and not just act like it.

That’s really helpful—thank you for sharing that. So, your values right now are about being genuine, having meaningful friendships, and taking care of yourself. Your goals are to stop self-harming, to feel happier and more authentic, and to reconnect with friends or build new relationships. We’ll focus on these together as we move forward, using a direct approach as you requested. Does that sound like a good starting point?

Thanks for trusting me with this. I want to get a clear picture of what’s going on so we can work on practical steps. Let’s start with your friends: can you tell me what changed? Was there a specific situation, or did things just slowly drift apart?

It kind of just happened over time. I feel like everybody already has their group, and I don’t really fit in anymore. I try to talk to people, but it feels forced or awkward. Sometimes I think people notice that I’m just pretending to be okay.

That sounds really tough. Losing that sense of belonging can make everything else feel worse. About your sleep—you mentioned it’s all over the place. Are you having trouble falling asleep, waking up in the night, or sleeping too much during the day?

Mostly I stay up way too late because I can’t turn my brain off. I’ll just scroll on my phone or listen to music because I feel so down at night. Then sometimes I oversleep and can’t get up for class, or I’m just tired all day.

Not getting enough rest can make everything feel heavier and even make urges to self-harm harder to fight. You mentioned changing in the locker room so people don’t see. That shows me you care about your own privacy and also might be feeling ashamed or worried about judgment. Have you hurt yourself recently, or are you mostly having urges right now?
It’s mostly urges, but they’re getting stronger. I haven’t actually cut, but I keep thinking about it, especially when I feel really angry or overwhelmed.

I’m really glad you’re telling me this directly. The fact you haven’t acted on the urges is important—it means you’re fighting, even if it doesn’t feel like it. I want to talk about what you do when those urges hit. Is there anything that helps you ride them out, even a little? Or do you mostly just grit your teeth and try to distract yourself?
Usually I just put my headphones in and listen to sad music, or I’ll scroll on my phone. Sometimes I squeeze an ice cube or scratch, but it doesn’t really make it go away.

Those are some coping strategies, but I can help you build better ones that are more likely to actually reduce the urge instead of just numbing out. Next session, I’ll give you a list of concrete things you can try in the moment. For now, I want you to keep track of what you do when you feel urges: what works even a little, and what doesn’t. That way, we’ll know what to focus on and what to swap out. How does that sound?

Thanks for coming back and being honest. Last time, you agreed to keep track of what you do when you have urges to self-harm—what makes them worse, what helps, and what doesn’t really do anything. Were you able to notice any patterns or things that seemed to help, even a little?

Yeah, I wrote some stuff down. When I listen to music or scroll on my phone, it sometimes distracts me for a while, but then I just end up feeling numb or more upset after. Squeezing an ice cube does help the urge a bit, but it’s not always enough. I noticed it’s a lot worse when I’m tired or after I have a bad day at school.

That’s really useful insight—you’ve noticed that lack of sleep and tough days at school make urges worse, and that some strategies like ice or music help a bit, but not enough. This tells me that part of the solution is making changes both in the moment, and overall. First, for the urges: I’m going to give you a direct list of things to try. When you feel the urge, try:

1. Get up and move—try doing 20 jumping jacks or going for a brisk walk. Intense movement can help your brain and body change gears.
2. Hold something cold (like ice) in your hand or run your wrists under cold water for 30 seconds.
3. Try the ‘rubber band’ method—snap a rubber band on your wrist, but not hard enough to hurt, just enough for sensation.
4. Text or message someone (even if it’s a distraction, it’s not isolating).
5. Write out exactly what you’re feeling, as messy as it comes, and then tear up the paper.

Will you pick 1 or 2 of these to try next time you have a strong urge, and let me know how it goes?
I’ll try the first one and the writing thing. Moving around sounds better than just lying there. I usually don’t want to, but maybe it’ll help. I can write stuff down too. I guess it can’t hurt.

That’s a solid plan. Even if it feels awkward or pointless at first, give it a real shot—the goal is to interrupt the cycle, even if it’s just for a few minutes. On the bigger stuff: since you noticed sleep makes everything worse, it’s important to set a firm time to start winding down each night (no screens after that time, if possible). Even 15 minutes earlier is a win. Pick a small, realistic sleep goal for this week—what time could you try to be off your phone and lying down?
I can try to be in bed by midnight and off my phone by then. I usually stay up until 2 or later, so I guess that’s better.

That’s a good, realistic goal. Set an alarm or reminder if you need to. Finally, about friends—building real connections takes time, but you don’t have to force it. Instead of focusing on fitting in, pick one person you feel even a little comfortable around, and try to have a short conversation with them this week. It doesn’t have to be deep. Just a step. Are you willing to try that?
Yeah, I can try. There’s one kid in my math class who seems okay. I’ll try to talk to him.

That’s all you need to do for now—one small step. So your goals for this week: use movement or writing when the urge comes, get to bed by midnight with no phone, and say a few words to that person in math. Write down how it goes, and tell me next time. If you slip up, we’ll deal with it together. Sound good?
Yeah. Thanks. That sounds good. I’ll try.

Thanks for checking in. I want to be direct: setbacks happen, especially when you’re trying to break old habits and change how you cope. That doesn’t mean you’ve failed or that you can’t get better. Can you tell me what happened this week—were you able to try any of the things we talked about, like moving around or writing things down when the urges hit? How did sleep and reaching out at school go?

Honestly, this week was rough. I tried to move around once when I had an urge, but it just made me feel restless and kind of angry. I wrote stuff down another night, but it ended up making me cry more. I couldn’t really stick to midnight for sleep. I kept scrolling on my phone until 1 or 2 again. And at school, I didn’t talk to that kid in math—I just felt too awkward. The urges to cut have been stronger, and I keep thinking about it, especially when I’m alone at night. I don’t know if I’m really getting better.

I hear you, and I want to be clear: you’re not back at square one. You tried some of the strategies, and even though they felt hard or didn’t fix things right away, that’s part of the process. New coping skills almost always feel weird or useless at first. The fact that you didn’t give in to the urge, even when it was strong, tells me you’re fighting harder than you think. 

Let’s get very practical. First, about sleep: scrolling on your phone at night keeps your brain wired and makes the depression and urges worse. Tonight, put your charger across the room so you have to get out of bed to reach your phone. If you can, turn on ‘Do Not Disturb’ by midnight, even if you’re not sleeping yet. The goal is progress, not perfection.

For the urges: When movement or writing feels bad, try a different tool. Fill a sink with cold water and dunk your face in for a few seconds, or grip something really cold. If that’s too much, try squeezing a stress ball or even tearing up paper. The key is to change the physical state of your body and break the cycle, no matter how small it seems.

About school: The first attempt is always the hardest. Next time you see that kid, just say 'hey' or ask a quick question about class. You don’t have to force a real conversation yet. That tiny bit of contact is what matters now.

Most important: If you feel like you’re getting close to hurting yourself, text a crisis line or reach out to a safe adult, even if it feels pointless. You don’t have to handle this alone. Do you think you can try these tweaks for the next few days, even if you slip up sometimes?

Yeah, I think I can try. I’ll put my phone farther away and try the cold water thing. I’ll try to just say hi to that kid too, even if it feels weird. I don’t want to go back to cutting. I’ll try to reach out if it gets really bad, but it’s hard. Thanks for being real with me.

You’re doing the work, even if it doesn’t feel like it. Setbacks are part of recovery, not the end of it. You have concrete steps: phone away at night, try cold water or a different physical strategy, and one small social step at school. If you have a rough night, message someone or text a helpline. Next time, tell me what felt even a tiny bit easier, and what still felt impossible—we’ll adjust together. You’re not alone in this.

Thanks for sticking with this and being honest, even though things have been rough. Directly: setbacks don’t erase your progress. You’re facing strong urges, but you’re still here and still trying changes, even if they feel small or uncomfortable. That’s important.

Let’s break down what happened since we last talked. Were you able to get your phone across the room, use cold water or another tool for the urges, or try that small social step at school? What felt a little easier (if anything), and what still felt impossible?

I did move my phone across the room a few nights. It sucked, but I did fall asleep faster. I tried the cold water thing once when I felt really bad, and it actually shocked me out of it for a few minutes—so that sort of helped. I said hi to that guy in math. It was awkward, but I did it. The urges are still pretty bad, especially at night, but I haven’t cut. I almost did one night, but I put music on and just tried to ride it out.

You did everything I asked you to try—that’s real progress, even if it doesn’t feel like much. Putting your phone away, trying cold water, and actually speaking to someone at school are all concrete steps. You’re learning which strategies shift your state (cold water helped, music helped a bit), and you’re fighting the urge every night. That’s you taking control, not the other way around.

The key insight here is: Even when things feel overwhelming, small, uncomfortable actions can interrupt the urge and keep you safe. You’re proving to yourself, step by step, that you can change your patterns.

Here’s what I want you to focus on for this week. 1) Keep the phone across the room every night, even if you slip up. 2) Whenever you have an urge, pick either cold water or another physical strategy (like squeezing something or tearing paper). 3) Try to have one more short real-life conversation at school, even if it’s just a sentence. 4) If an urge feels like it’s getting too close, message a helpline or a safe person—don’t wait until it’s out of control.

Are you willing to agree to these tasks, and write down which ones felt even a little bit easier by next session? We’ll use that to fine-tune your plan.

Yeah, I can do that. I’ll keep moving my phone, use the cold water or something else if I get urges, and I’ll try to talk to someone else at school. I’ll write down what feels easier or harder and let you know. Thanks for helping me not give up.

You’re showing real grit by coming back and trying again, even when it’s hard. You have a clear plan for the week, and you know exactly what to watch for. Write down what you try and how it feels, and we’ll keep building on the things that make a difference for you. You’re not in this fight alone.

Thanks for coming back and sticking with the plan. I want to hear how things went this week with the specific strategies we talked about—keeping your phone across the room at night, using cold water or a physical strategy when you had urges, and trying another short conversation at school. Which things felt any easier, and which were still tough? Let’s get straight to what worked and what didn’t, so we can adjust your plan if needed.

So I kept my phone away most nights, but one night I needed it for an alarm because I had to get up extra early. I ended up scrolling again that night because it was right next to me. I used cold water twice this week when I felt on edge, and it helped a bit, but one time I was at a friend’s house and didn’t know what to do because I didn’t want to explain why I was suddenly going to the bathroom just to use cold water. Also, I tried talking to another person at school, but it was in a group and I barely said anything. I wrote this down but I’m not sure if it “counts” or if I’m doing it right.
